attributes.title: Priming Politics and Attitudes on the National Football League

q1.value: Priming Politics and Attitudes on the National Football League

q2.value: John W. Givens | J. Benjamin Taylor

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In the last decade, the National Football League (NFL) has become the most popular sports entertainment option in the United States, overtaking baseball and other professional sports. The NFL’s championship game, The Super Bowl, is the most watched television event in the United States every year. Yet in an increasingly sorted, partisan, and divided United States, (e.g., Hetherington and Weiler 2018) “[p]ro football is unique in that its fandom stretches across partisan lines” (Paine, Eten, and Jones-Rooy 2017). In recent years, the NFL has faced two major controversies. First, evidence has mounted that the sport causes major brain trauma in its players, specifically chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) (Aschwanden 2018). Second, players have protested police brutality and racism by kneeling during the national anthem. The movement was started by Colin Kaepernick who remains unsigned by any NFL franchise, likely as a result of his protest (ESPN News Service 2016). These issues have caused the NFL trouble in public relations and are highly politically salient. President Trump has inserted himself into these controversies, coming out strongly against not only the national anthem protest, but also against rules designed to protect players from brain injuries (Payne 2017). As partisanship and ideology are increasingly pertinent to economic and lifestyle decisions Americans make, understanding how these controversies are affected by partisanship and ideology is an important empirical and theoretical question. As one of the United States’ few remaining bi-partisan cultural and media products the NFL offers unique insight into a divided country. RQ 1: How does ideology/partisanship affect engagement with the NFL? Expectations: Based on previous research we expect that liberals, moderates, and conservatives to report watching roughly the same amount of NFL (Paine, Eten, and Jones-Rooy 2017). RQ 2: How does ideology/partisanship affect exposure to different NFL controversies? Expectations: We expect left-leaning individuals to report watching more NFL when they are primed to think about the NFL’s Players Coalition’s efforts to provide funding for criminal justice reform, law enforcement/community relations, and education. However, we expect left-leaning individuals to say they watch less when they are primed to think about players suffering from CTE or Colin Kaepernick’s situation and inability to get signed by a team. In the unlikely event that our survey captures sufficient numbers of pro-Trump liberals, we expect none of the treatments to have an effect. We expect reported NFL viewing among political moderates (with middle-ground feelings towards Trump) to be unaffected by all treatments except CTE. However, because of the way in which the President has inserted himself into the controversies, we expect that among pro-Trump moderates there will be a negative effect associated with the Player’s Coalition, a positive effect associated with Colin Kaepernick’s situation, and no effect from the CTE issue. We expect that among anti-Trump moderates there will be a positive effect associated with the Player’s Coalition, a negative effect associated with Colin Kaepernick’s situation, and a negative effect from the CTE issue. Finally, we expect reported NFL viewing among right-leaning individuals to be affected negatively by the player’s coalition and positively by the Kaepernick situation. We expect them to be unaffected by the treatments related to CTE. However, we expect that among anti-Trump conservatives (should there be sufficient numbers in the survey) there will be a no effect associated with the Player’s Coalition or Kaepernick’s situation and a negative effect associated with the CTE issue. RQ 3: What effect do feelings toward Pres. Trump have on attitudes about the NFL? Because Pres. Trump has taken a keen interest in the goings-on of the NFL, particularly related to Kaepernick (e.g., see Graham 2017), it may be the case that feelings toward him, specifically, can affect how attitudes about the NFL over and above ideology or partisanship. As such, we propose the following hypotheses interacting treatment conditions with a feeling thermometer for Pres. Trump. We measure feelings toward President Trump two ways: using objective measures (35 or below is “negative,” 36 – 65 is “neutral,” 66 and above is “positive”) and we use relative measures as a test as well (Trump minus 1SD+ is “relatively negative,” Trump mean is “relatively neutral,” and Trump plus 1SD+ is “relatively positive).

q16.value: Table 1: Predicted relationship between treatment, political orientation and reported viewing Treatment Left Leaning Moderate Right Leaning Effects for Ideology Only Control No Effect No Effect No Effect Player’s Coalition Positive No Effect Negative Kaepernick & Protest Negative No Effect Positive Brain Trauma Negative Negative Negative Effects for Interacting Ideology + Trump Feelings Control No Effect No Effect No Effect Player’s Coalition No effect if pro-Trump Negative if pro-Trump, positive if anti-trump No effect if anti-Trump Kaepernick & Protest No effect if pro-Trump Positive if pro-Trump, negative if anti-trump No effect if anti-Trump Brain Trauma no effect if pro-Trump no effect if pro-Trump Negative if anti-Trump Table 2: Predicted relationship between treatment and Trump Feeling Therm. Treatment Trump Negative Trump Neutral Trump Positive Control No Effect No Effect No Effect Player’s Coalition Positive No Effect Negative Kaepernick & Protest Negative No Effect Positive Brain Trauma Negative Negative No Effect

q17.value: We will use t-tests and regression analysis.

First, evidence has mounted that the sport causes major brain trauma in its players, specifically chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) (Aschwanden 2018). Second, players have protested police brutality and racism by kneeling during the national anthem. The movement was started by Colin Kaepernick who remains unsigned by any NFL franchise, likely as a result of his protest (ESPN News Service 2016). attributes.title: Long-run Effects of Non-Food Item Vouchers in a Humanitarian Context: The Case of the Rapid Response to Movements of Population Program in Congo

q1.value: Long-run Effects of Non-Food Item Vouchers in a Humanitarian Context: The Case of the Rapid Response to Movements of Population Program in Congo

q2.value: John Quattrochi | Ghislain Bisimwa | Maarten Voors | Peter Van der Windt

q5.value: We would like to thank Tyler Thompson for excellent research assistance and Alexandra Blason, Yannick Brand, Gabriele Erba, Mia Jeong, Steven Michel, Pacifique Mugaruka, Anna Orlanidni, Aude Rigot, and Frederic Unterreiner at UNICEF for their comments and suggestions. We are grateful to seminar participants at the Harvard Humanitarian Initiative and the Harvard Center for Population and Development Studies, and to Jenny Aker, Jeremy Barofsky, Chris Blattman, Günther Fink, and Heather Lanthorn for comments and suggestions. We gratefully acknowledge funding from the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation (3ie). All mistakes and errors are our own.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In 2017 and 2018, we conducted a field experiment in 31 villages in Eastern Congo, to learn about the impact of Non-Food Item (NFI) vouchers on 1) physical health, 2) mental health, 3) social cohesion, and 4) resilience. Data was originally collected around six weeks after the distribution of the vouchers. The pre-analysis plan was registered at EGAP (http://egap.org/registration/2832). More information about the intervention, how the original outcomes are measured, and study context can be found in that document. Here, we outline a plan to revisit the same villages about one year after the distribution of vouchers to understand 1) the long-run effects of the NFI vouchers on the same four outcomes, 2) the effects of NFI vouchers on women’s empowerment, and 3) the effects of the NFI vouchers on (onward or return) migration.

q16.value: We aim to answer the following questions: 1. What are the effects of humanitarian assistance after 6-12 months on adult mental health, child physical health, social cohesion, and resilience? 2. What are the effects of humanitarian assistance after 6-12 months on women’s empowerment? 3. Does receipt of humanitarian assistance influence the decision to migrate?

q17.value: The original data collection effort consisted of two rounds of surveys. We interviewed respondents from about 1,500 households (in almost 1,000 dwellings) before the intervention and around six weeks after the intervention. As part of this data collection exercise, we will revisit the same villages, and aim to re-interview the same people that were interviewed as part of the baseline. The survey that will be conducted with these individuals is almost identical to the second survey wave. We made some changes to the initial questions required to identify households, and we added two sets of questions about women’s empowerment and migration (see below). We aim to collect the data in the fall of 2018 and first quarter of 2019. We will first undertake the data collection in five villages. We may not collect data in the subsequent villages if any one of the following holds: 1) It is not safe to visit the locations (for security reasons, Ebola, etc.), or 2) if in the first villages less than 25% of baseline respondents can be re-interviewed.

q24.value: The original IRB protocols have been amended and approved (New York University #064-2017).

attributes.title: Analyzing Impacts of Awareness Campaigns in Increasing Electricity Consumption Amongst Under-Consumers of Electricity in an Off-Grid Microgrid Setting

q1.value: Analyzing Impacts of Awareness Campaigns in Increasing Electricity Consumption Amongst Under-Consumers of Electricity in an Off-Grid Microgrid Setting

q2.value: Ryan Kennedy | Carson Whisler | Sudi Mungkasi | Florianus Nay

q5.value: This research was supported supported by the Fulbright Foundation. We thank our colleagues from ISEP who provided insight and expertise that greatly assisted the research, although they may not agree with all of the interpretations/conclusions of this paper.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Microgrid providers are currently implementing a business model wherein customers are required to purchase a minimum “packet” of electricity each month. Customers purchase this minimum energy packet with the understanding that any electricity that is not used will not carry over to the next month. Therefore, if they use less than this amount of energy each month they are subjecting themselves to a higher payment per unit of energy they use. This study aims to test how customers’ awareness around their current electricity usage versus the minimum packet of energy available to them impacts their electricity consumption decisions. If customers that do not consume more than the minimum packet are not aware that they are currently underconsuming electricity, we hypothesize that this will cause them to be risk averse about reaching their packet limit, running out of electricity, and having to buy more. The study sites provide an interesting environment to test this theory. Currently, customers are not able to easily check the amount of electricity they have used at a given moment. Meters that track their electricity usage are placed atop electricity poles to prevent theft. Automated systems that would allow them to receive information about electricity usage through a mobile application or text message are not able to run properly because sites are remote and do not receive strong cell phone reception. They are only able to access this information if they actively seek it out by finding their village sales agent or a member of the microgrid provider’s technical staff. Thus, we plan to deploy a survey to capture information related to customers’ current electricity consumption behaviors and capacity for consumption. This will provide information about customers’ current appliance usage, along with their knowledge of electricity usage versus electricity available. We will then provide half of the households that have never consumed the minimum energy packet with additional information about their current usage and how they may be able to productively use the remaining electricity available to them.

q16.value: We expect the intervention to significantly increase the amount of electricity consumption among treatment households as compared to households in the control group. Quantities of interest will be kilowatt hours of monthly electricity consumption. We will measure electricity consumption data provided by the microgrid provider’s smart metering systems. We will analyze growth in kilowatt hours consumed by this group of underconsumers and compare between the treatment group and the non-treatment group using regression analysis. We will also analyze this in the context of growth in electricity consumption amongst customers at research sites as whole. Other variables of interest that may impact outcome variables include awareness around electricity consumption. The first of these is the consumers’ knowledge of how to check their electricity usage at microgrid sites. The second of these will be the frequency with which these consumers check their consumption. Finally, we will ask those who know how to check their energy consumption to estimate their consumption using measurements of both electricity consumption (kilowatt hours) and electricity balance (Indonesian Rupiah). Our treatment instrument will help us understand how receiving additional information about electricity consumption impacts underconsumers’ electricity consumption in the context of the minimum electricity packet.

q17.value: We will test these hypotheses using a survey instrument and using a randomized treatment that provides additional information about household energy consumption to half of the households. We will use a difference in differences analysis to analyze how the treatment impacts electricity consumption amongst underconsumers of energy.

q23.value: currently undergoing IRB approval after revisions. Approval is expected in the next week, as revisions were submitted last Friday.

attributes.title: Who Cares? Measuring Attitude Strength in a Polarized Environment

q1.value: Who Cares? Measuring Attitude Strength in a Polarized Environment

q2.value: Charlotte Cavaille | Daniel L. Chen | Karine Van der Straeten

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q19.value: 3600 survey respondents, all over 18, US citizens

registration_responses.q1: Who Cares? Measuring Attitude Strength in a Polarized Environment
registration_responses.q2: Charlotte Cavaille | Daniel L. Chen | Karine Van der Straeten
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q19: 3600 survey respondents, all over 18, US citizens

attributes.title: Speciesism and the Connection to Other Human Prejudices

q1.value: Speciesism and the Connection to Other Human Prejudices

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Intergroup prejudice has been recognized by scholars as one of the most significant problems facing societies across the world. Though extensive research has produced a large body of work that examines and elucidates the origins of prejudice and how it operates at the cognitive, individual, and group level, there has been little success reducing it through interventions (Paluck and Green 2009). This project aims to provide evidence for a link between speciesism – or the assignment of moral worth based on species membership – and racism and sexism. Through an intervention intended to reduce individual speciesism, I hope to show that there will be a durable reduction in prejudicial sexist and racist attitudes as well.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1: Treatment group has lower speciesism Hypothesis 2: Treatment group has lower scores on all prejudicial attitudes Hypothesis 3: The effect in Hypothesis 2 is mediated by speciesism Hypothesis 4: Lower prejudicial attitudes (the effect) may be more pronounced in the old-fashioned versions (for example, old-fashioned sexism and racisms Q’s) Hypothesis 5: Speciesism → kindness → lower prejudicial attitudes Hypothesis 5b: Treatment group exhibits greater perspective-taking abilities Hypothesis 6: Speciesism → SDO → lower prejudicial attitude Hypothesis 7: Those who put in more cognitive effort are more likely to see an effect (i.e., reduction in prejudicial attitudes). Hypothesis 8: Lowering speciesism also impacts behavior, yielding preferences for more universal, less nationalist policies. Hypothesis 9: Subgroups that are relevant are gender-based (women may see more of a pronounced effect or an effect period), ideology-based (liberals are more open to experience, and generally might be less resistant to this kind of priming/information), there could be an age thing going as well (folk below 30-40 might be less resistant as the vegan movement has grown recently).

q17.value: They will be tested via a regression model (quantitatively)

attributes.title: The determinants of work motivation among public employees

q1.value: The determinants of work motivation among public employees

q5.value: Many thanks Henry Fung for all of his time and efforts in assisting in the preparation of this PAP, and to Mai Hassan and Martin Williams for their wise comments on earlier drafts.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The purpose of this study is to examine the relationship between management practices, work environment factors, and the motivation and attitudes of civil servants. This PAP covers analysis of observational data to be used as part of a broader book project (and possibly related journal articles) centered on Mission-Driven Bureaucrats. The analysis of existing observational data is intended to establish whether broad patterns exist across different public sector contexts, providing context and (if confirmed) generalizability to narrower new empirical projects undertaken as part of this work stream.

q16.value: Our study tests observable implications of four main hypotheses: (H1) There are management practice-motivation equilibria. In equilibrium, when management practice is supportive and sufficient autonomy is present, employee motivation is higher; when management practice is not supportive and sufficient autonomy not present, motivation is lower. (H2) Organizational equilibria are dynamic over time. As management practice changes, this induces changes in the motivation of employees. This happens through “treatment” (changes to the existing employees) and “selection” (changing composition of employees). (H3) Peer effects are relevant in sustaining good (and bad) equilibria. (H4) Not all public sector jobs are created equal; where tasks cannot be tightly observed and verified, the dynamics above are more important/effect sizes are larger.

q17.value: These hypotheses are drawn from a larger project, which incorporates a variety of data not covered by this PAP (from empirical projects in Thailand, Bangladesh, the US (Detroit), and possibly India and Ghana as well). The analysis of administrative data under this PAP, then, is a complement to other efforts, rather than a stand-alone test meant to provide sufficient evidence to convincingly support all of these hypotheses on their own. Relatedly, we are not able to make strong causal claims in these administrative data, and do not mean to imply by use of the word “equilibrium” that that is the case. Rather, what administrative data allows is correlational evidence consistent with these hypotheses. We might find that – to (H1), for example – more supportive management practices are associated with higher levels of motivation, and – to (H2) – changes within-agency in management practice over time are associated with changes in employee motivation. These are observable implications of (H1) and (H2) but are not meant to be fully conclusive tests of (H1) and (H2) (or e.g. speak to “selection” vs. “treatment” dynamics of (H2) at all). As articulated below, we can examine these relationships (depending on the dataset) across agency, across individual, and within-agency over time (where there are repeated cross-sections/many years of data present). 1. Using our test datasets, we will specify a set of linear regression models based on data exploration and feature selection techniques after the registration of this PAP. • The results from cross-sectional and panel regression models will provide suggestive evidence for (H1) and (H2) respectively. • To test (H3), we will also examine in our models the relationships between coworkers’ competence and behaviour and employee attitudes in the Australia APS, United Kingdom CSPS, and India datasets. Note that the regression models from test datasets may be similar, but not identical to those that were developed from the FEVS and EPS data. This is because items in the test datasets are only related to some, but not all variables in the FEVS and EPS models. • To test hypothesis (H4), the agencies/government services from the PSES, CSPS, and the India datasets will be categorized based on the verifiability of their tasks. Both I and a research assistant or Ph.D. student will code the agencies as “largely verifiable”, “largely unverifiable”, or “unsure”. Only those cases where both of us have assigned the same agency to “verifiable” or “unverifiable” will form part of the categories. Subsequently, a set of linear regression models with interaction terms between management practices and organizational category dummy variables will be specified. 2. We will examine whether the regression results from the test datasets support hypotheses (H1) to (H4), and how they compare to the stylized facts of the hypothesis datasets in Appendix D.

q18.value: United States, Australia, Canada, United Kingdom, India

q21.value: No, as there was no data collection by researchers (in the sense of survey or field experiment) – this registration is for an analysis of pre-existing observational data.

q23.value: No, as it entirely uses administrative data already in the public domain. C8 and C9 are thus left blank.

registration_responses.q1: The determinants of work motivation among public employees
registration_responses.q5: Many thanks Henry Fung for all of his time and efforts in assisting in the preparation of this PAP, and to Mai Hassan and Martin Williams for their wise comments on earlier drafts.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: The purpose of this study is to examine the relationship between management practices, work environment factors, and the motivation and attitudes of civil servants. This PAP covers analysis of observational data to be used as part of a broader book project (and possibly related journal articles) centered on Mission-Driven Bureaucrats. The analysis of existing observational data is intended to establish whether broad patterns exist across different public sector contexts, providing context and (if confirmed) generalizability to narrower new empirical projects undertaken as part of this work stream.
registration_responses.q16: Our study tests observable implications of four main hypotheses: (H1) There are management practice-motivation equilibria. In equilibrium, when management practice is supportive and sufficient autonomy is present, employee motivation is higher; when management practice is not supportive and sufficient autonomy not present, motivation is lower. (H2) Organizational equilibria are dynamic over time. As management practice changes, this induces changes in the motivation of employees. This happens through “treatment” (changes to the existing employees) and “selection” (changing composition of employees). (H3) Peer effects are relevant in sustaining good (and bad) equilibria. (H4) Not all public sector jobs are created equal; where tasks cannot be tightly observed and verified, the dynamics above are more important/effect sizes are larger.
registration_responses.q17: These hypotheses are drawn from a larger project, which incorporates a variety of data not covered by this PAP (from empirical projects in Thailand, Bangladesh, the US (Detroit), and possibly India and Ghana as well). The analysis of administrative data under this PAP, then, is a complement to other efforts, rather than a stand-alone test meant to provide sufficient evidence to convincingly support all of these hypotheses on their own. Relatedly, we are not able to make strong causal claims in these administrative data, and do not mean to imply by use of the word “equilibrium” that that is the case. Rather, what administrative data allows is correlational evidence consistent with these hypotheses. We might find that – to (H1), for example – more supportive management practices are associated with higher levels of motivation, and – to (H2) – changes within-agency in management practice over time are associated with changes in employee motivation. These are observable implications of (H1) and (H2) but are not meant to be fully conclusive tests of (H1) and (H2) (or e.g. speak to “selection” vs. “treatment” dynamics of (H2) at all). As articulated below, we can examine these relationships (depending on the dataset) across agency, across individual, and within-agency over time (where there are repeated cross-sections/many years of data present). 1. Using our test datasets, we will specify a set of linear regression models based on data exploration and feature selection techniques after the registration of this PAP. • The results from cross-sectional and panel regression models will provide suggestive evidence for (H1) and (H2) respectively. • To test (H3), we will also examine in our models the relationships between coworkers’ competence and behaviour and employee attitudes in the Australia APS, United Kingdom CSPS, and India datasets. Note that the regression models from test datasets may be similar, but not identical to those that were developed from the FEVS and EPS data. This is because items in the test datasets are only related to some, but not all variables in the FEVS and EPS models. • To test hypothesis (H4), the agencies/government services from the PSES, CSPS, and the India datasets will be categorized based on the verifiability of their tasks. Both I and a research assistant or Ph.D. student will code the agencies as “largely verifiable”, “largely unverifiable”, or “unsure”. Only those cases where both of us have assigned the same agency to “verifiable” or “unverifiable” will form part of the categories. Subsequently, a set of linear regression models with interaction terms between management practices and organizational category dummy variables will be specified. 2. We will examine whether the regression results from the test datasets support hypotheses (H1) to (H4), and how they compare to the stylized facts of the hypothesis datasets in Appendix D.

attributes.title: Can You Have It Both Ways? Plausible Deniability and Coercive Effectiveness

q1.value: Can You Have It Both Ways? Plausible Deniability and Coercive Effectiveness

q2.value: Costantino Pischedda | Sara Bjerg Moller | Andrew Cheon

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The project tackles the puzzle of plausibly deniable coercive acts, i.e., actions undertaken by states or non-state actors aimed at influencing the behavior of other actors through the infliction of some costs, whose perpetrators either fail to claim or deny responsibility. Examples include the 2014 cyber-attack against Sony and presumably a substantial share of terrorist attacks, the vast majority of which go unclaimed. Plausibly deniable coercive acts are puzzling because Thomas Schelling suggests coercive success relies on the clarity of the underlying message: the target needs to understand that the threat is contingent on its behavior, what is being required, and the consequences of non-compliance. Not knowing the identity of the coercer may make the target unsure as to what is being demanded, what costs non-compliance will entail, and whether the perpetrator will stop if compliance is forthcoming, rendering coercive success less likely. Extant thinking suggests a straightforward, but unconvincing answer: plausible deniability offers the coercer the benefit of being shielded from retaliation by other audiences (third-party states, international organizations or domestic constituencies). Moreover, to the extent that third parties remain uncertain, the perpetrator could be shielded from retaliation by the target also, as the latter might be deterred from retaliating lest third parties interpret its actions as aggressive rather than retributive. The problem with this answer is that the benefit in question comes at the cost of coercive effectiveness, making plausible deniability self-defeating: Given the same information, rationalist arguments would lead us to expect both the target and third parties to reach the same conclusions about the identity of the perpetrator. Coercive success would imply that the target and third parties have correctly identified the perpetrator, nullifying the benefit of being shielded from retaliation. Conversely, if third parties withhold retaliation because they are unsure, the target should remain similarly unsure, leading to coercive failure.

q16.value: We hypothesize that the target and third parties may reach different conclusions about responsibility for unclaimed/plausibly denied coercive actions based on different emotional responses. Political psychology suggests that people’s beliefs are powerfully influenced by emotions. Emotions affect the way evidence is selected and interpreted; positive feelings about someone may lead one to discount evidence that the person may not be trustworthy. Emotions may even be used as independent evidence in support of one’s beliefs; positive feelings about someone may be offered as a justification for trusting the person. By the same token, the target of a coercive action is likely to experience a more intense emotional response, involving relatively high levels of fear, anxiety, or anger, than an audience that is not directly affected. These intense emotions, in turn, would make the target less likely than third parties to believe claims of non-involvement and more likely to conclude that what appears as the most plausible culprit is in fact responsible. Therefore, the coercer “could have it both ways” if the target correctly identifies the culprit (thus making compliance possible), while third parties remain uncertain about the identity of the perpetrators (thus withholding sanctions). By contrast, emotions should not have a substantial effect on attribution of responsibility when the evidence about who committed the attack is unambiguous.

q17.value: We test our emotional beliefs argument with survey experiments exposing different subject pools to fictional scenarios in which various types of attacks (terrorist attack, cyber attack, and conventional covert action) have occurred and eliciting information on their emotional state as well as on their beliefs about the identity of the perpetrator and the appropriateness of responses to the attack. The experimental treatment consists of information about the relationship between the subject and the target country: the target is either the subject’s country or another country. In the first experiment, all subjects are told that media and intelligence agencies have identified a certain actor as the likely culprit, but that the actor has not claimed responsibility. In the second experiment, all subjects are told that media and intelligence agencies have identified a certain actor as the likely culprit and that the actor has claimed responsibility. This set up results in four subject pools: A (the target is the subject’s own country, the attack is unclaimed); B (the target is another country, the attack is unclaimed); C (the target is subject’s own country, the attack is claimed); D (the target is another country, the attack is claimed). Our theoretical expectation is that subjects told that their own country was targeted by an unclaimed attack (group A) will display more intense emotional reactions, and thus express higher confidence in the responsibility of the suspected perpetrator, than subjects told that some other country was targeted by an unclaimed attack (group B). By contrast, we do not expect a substantial difference in assessments of responsibility of a claimed attack between subjects told that their own country was attacked (group C) and subjects told that some other country was attacked (group D).

attributes.title: Preanalysis Plan for “Effects of Disclosure on Use of Campaign Finance Vouchers”

q1.value: Preanalysis Plan for “Effects of Disclosure on Use of Campaign Finance Vouchers”

q2.value: Abby K. Wood | Christopher S. Elmendorf

q5.value: We appreciate funding from the MIT Election Data Science Lab to support this project.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The voters of Seattle and South Dakota recently enacted the first-ever programs of publicly funded campaign finance vouchers. The two programs take diametrically opposite approaches to disclosure. In Seattle, every voucher contribution is of public record; the contributor and the recipient are named. In South Dakota (whose program has since been repealed by statute) voucher contributions were to be confidential unless the contributor supplemented the publicly-funded voucher with money of her own. Under both statutes, disclosure seems to have been an afterthought, notwithstanding growing concern in some quarters that mandatory disclosure of privately funded campaign contributions may “chill” or “distort” such political speech. Whatever may be the effects of disclosure on privately funded contributions, there is some basis for thinking that analogous disclosure requirements for publicly financed vouchers may have considerably larger effects on participation. The reason is that disclosure requirements on privately funded contributions affect only the very small – and relatively wealthy – population of Americans who give or would give (depending on the disclosure regime) their own money to candidates for elective office. Only about 1% of U.S. citizens give their own money to candidates. Voucher programs distribute publicly funded vouchers to all registered voters, a population that seems likely to include proportionately more socially and economically vulnerable individuals. Using a survey experiment, we provide an initial test of the effects of disclosure on voucher contributions. We compare three disclosure paradigms: full anonymity (a voucher regime modeled on the secret ballot), full disclosure (a voucher regime modeled on Seattle’s program), and an intermediate, “semi-disclosure” regime in which geocoded voucher contribution histories for each voter are publicly disclosed, but without any personal identifying information.

q16.value: Until now, two ideas have shaped legal-academic debates about the effect of disclosure on political speech (here, political contributions). The courts assume that disclosure may “chill” speech by those who do not want their political contributions to be made public. Mike Gilbert has written that disclosure can also attract or “thaw” speech from those who seek to “go on record” as having donated, because disclosure regimes lower the cost to would-be contributors of credibly communicating their political preferences to the world. To date, these competing hypotheses have not been tested. Because “chilling” and “thawing” effects described in the theory section of the PAP may cancel out, we have no prior beliefs about the effect of disclosure (or semi-disclosure) on the proportion of the population who participates. However, we expect disclosure to change which members of the eligible-voucher-donor population elect to participate, chilling participation by people whose political preferences are not aligned with those of their social network or employer, and thawing participation by people whose preferences are closely aligned. Among people who would participate in all three regimes, we expect disclosure to increase insincere giving, with the effects concentrated among people who are most cross-pressured and economically vulnerable. However, this hypothesis presumes that there are few if any “raiding”- type contributions in the no-disclosure condition, i.e., contributions to the least electable candidate of the opposing party. If raiding does occur in the no-disclosure regime, then disclosure may increase sincere giving, as raiding may be socially disapproved and thus decreasing in the level of disclosure.

q17.value: The experiment is conducted in a two-wave panel. In the first wave, we give respondents ranking tasks. Respondents rank six presidential candidates according to, respectively, their own preferences, the preferences of people in their social networks, and the preferences of their employer. Finally, we elicit the respondent’s own self-reported donations (if any) to candidates in the 2016 presidential election. In the second wave, we initially assign respondents to one of four treatment conditions: either the status quo (no vouchers); or a full-anonymity, semi-disclosure, or full-disclosure voucher regime in which the respondent may allocate $100 of public funds among the same candidates. We elicit the respondent’s intended own-money and voucher (public money) contributions under that regime. We then assign the respondent to each of the other three experimental vignettes (in random order), and elicit the same donation intentions. We consider responses from the first vignette to which the respondent was assigned to be that respondent’s “primary response,” and we will use only primary responses (which by construction cannot be affected by the other treatments) in most analyses. However, if KS tests indicate that there’s not a significant difference between the distribution of responses to a vignette when it is presented first, versus when it is presented later in the wave 2 survey, we will also report results using all responses for additional power. As well, if the KS tests are negative, we will conduct a “sincerity” analysis using a within-subjects design, explained below.

q24.value: At U.C. Davis, 1080344-1. At USC, UP-17-00407

q27.value: Bovitz survey firm will send the Qualtrics link to their panel, but we make the Qualtrics instrument live and collect the data directly.

attributes.title: How do Brazilian voters trade school quality and other government outputs when evaluating municipal politicians?

q1.value: How do Brazilian voters trade school quality and other government outputs when evaluating municipal politicians?

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In a working paper (“Evaluating students and politicians: Test scores and electoral accountability in Brazil”), we find that voters who receive information about the performance of municipal schools are less likely to vote for the incumbent when such signals are positive than when they are negative. This goes against established theories of retrospective voting and electoral accountability. Our findings stem from two research designs and two datasets from Brazil. First, in a regression discontinuity design (RDD) exploiting data for the municipal elections of 2008, 2012 and 2016 across Brazil, we study the effect of municipalities meeting a highly visible school quality target (IDEB) on electoral outcomes. Second, in a randomized controlled trial (RCT) in a sample of municipalities in Pernambuco, we study the effect of informing voters before the election about their municipality’s rank in the performance in an early student assessment (ANA) on individual vote choice. Contrary to expectations, we find in both the RDD and the RCT that signals about school quality decrease rather than increase electoral support for the incumbent. In the RDD, we find that municipalities that meet the IDEB target have a lower vote share for the mayor than those that miss their target. In the RCT, we find that voters are less likely to vote for the mayor the better the performance of the municipal schools.

q16.value: The main hypothesis stemming from the RCT and the RDD is that voters are less likely to vote for the incumbent when they receive positive signals about the quality of public schools (H1). The main goal of the survey is to explain this counter-intuitive finding. We have developed a number of hypotheses that could explain it: Trade-off hypotheses: • H2: Education quality vs public jobs trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they perceive a trade-off between the quality of schools and the number of people employed by the municipality (in education or other sectors) or, more generally, a trade-off between government performance and jobs. • H3: Education quality vs healthcare quality trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they perceive a trade-off between improving the quality of municipal schools and the quality of municipal clinics, which they value more. • H4: Education quality vs poverty alleviation trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they perceive a trade-off between the quality of municipal schools and the municipal government’s efforts at reducing poverty, which they value more. • H5: Education quality vs government responsiveness trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they see politicians who improve school quality as less responsive to their needs. Mediated trade-off hypotheses: • H6: People who give less importance to education, relative to other policy areas, are more likely to punish the incumbent when informed about good school performance because they perceive such information as a signal of the incumbent not prioritizing their interests. • H7: Parents (H7a), parents of primary- and middle-school aged children (H7b), or parents of primary- and middle-school aged children enrolled in municipal schools (H7c) have a direct stake in education quality and thus respond positively to good school quality signals (i.e., in the opposite direction than hypothesized in H1-H5). We expect parents with a more direct stake in school quality to respond more positively to good school quality signals (i.e. our prior belief about the likelihood of these sub-hypotheses is higher for H7c than for H7b, and higher for H7b than for H7a).

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, we will conduct a short online survey with Brazilian respondents recruited via Facebook. The core of the survey is an information experiment, which will be preceded by some questions that help us collect pre-treatment covariates and simulate the conditions in which voters make decisions during electoral campaigns. Before the experiment we will expose respondents to a battery of questions about how important they think different policy areas are for their personal interests. In particular, respondents will be asked to rank improvements in education, healthcare, employment in the municipal sector, economic activity in general, security, and fight against poverty. This will allow us to (i) collect data about saliency of different policy areas for voters; and (ii) prime respondents to think about the importance of different policy areas, and thus simulate the conditions in which voters decide their vote during electoral campaigns. Immediately before the experiment, we will inform voters about IDEB (what it is and what it means for a municipality to meet its IDEB target), and ask them whether they had already heard about it. Rather than use a vignette experiment with information about a hypothetical mayor, we provide real-world information about the performance of the mayor (or former mayor) of the respondent's self-reported municipality. Respondents will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: control (where they are not given information about whether their municipality met its target) and treatment (where they are informed about whether their municipality met its school quality target, as per the data published in 2016). Those in the treatment group read the following question: “In the year 2016, at the end of the term of Mayor [Name], [Municipality] [did not achieve / achieved] its IDEB target. Have you heard about that result?” The treatment information is accompanied by two images designed to reinforce the message: a photograph of the mayor (obtained from the official repository of the Supreme Electoral Court) and a red cross or a green checkmark, depending on the municipality's IDEB performance. Those assigned to the control group do not read any version of this question or a substitute. Next, all respondents, regardless of random assignment, read the following text: "Thinking about [Mayor], do you agree or disagree with the following statements about [his/her] term as Mayor of [municipality] during the period 2012–2016?" Response options are on a 4-point Likert scale ("totally agree", "partially agree", "partially disagree", "totally disagree"). To collect outcome data, we will ask about their agreement with the following statements, with the order of items randomized within respondents: • As mayor, he/she hired a lot of public servants. • As mayor, he/she improved municipal health clinics. • As mayor, he/she helped people like you solve problems. • As mayor, he/she reduced poverty in the municipality. • As mayor, he/she improved municipal schools. • As mayor, he/she invested a lot of money in education. After these main outcomes, we will ask respondents whether they would vote for that mayor if they were to run for another term, again with response options being in a 4-point Likert scale from "great chance" to "no chance".

registration_responses.q16: The main hypothesis stemming from the RCT and the RDD is that voters are less likely to vote for the incumbent when they receive positive signals about the quality of public schools (H1). The main goal of the survey is to explain this counter-intuitive finding. We have developed a number of hypotheses that could explain it: Trade-off hypotheses: • H2: Education quality vs public jobs trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they perceive a trade-off between the quality of schools and the number of people employed by the municipality (in education or other sectors) or, more generally, a trade-off between government performance and jobs. • H3: Education quality vs healthcare quality trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they perceive a trade-off between improving the quality of municipal schools and the quality of municipal clinics, which they value more. • H4: Education quality vs poverty alleviation trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they perceive a trade-off between the quality of municipal schools and the municipal government’s efforts at reducing poverty, which they value more. • H5: Education quality vs government responsiveness trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they see politicians who improve school quality as less responsive to their needs. Mediated trade-off hypotheses: • H6: People who give less importance to education, relative to other policy areas, are more likely to punish the incumbent when informed about good school performance because they perceive such information as a signal of the incumbent not prioritizing their interests. • H7: Parents (H7a), parents of primary- and middle-school aged children (H7b), or parents of primary- and middle-school aged children enrolled in municipal schools (H7c) have a direct stake in education quality and thus respond positively to good school quality signals (i.e., in the opposite direction than hypothesized in H1-H5). We expect parents with a more direct stake in school quality to respond more positively to good school quality signals (i.e. our prior belief about the likelihood of these sub-hypotheses is higher for H7c than for H7b, and higher for H7b than for H7a).
registration_responses.q17: To test these hypotheses, we will conduct a short online survey with Brazilian respondents recruited via Facebook. The core of the survey is an information experiment, which will be preceded by some questions that help us collect pre-treatment covariates and simulate the conditions in which voters make decisions during electoral campaigns. Before the experiment we will expose respondents to a battery of questions about how important they think different policy areas are for their personal interests. In particular, respondents will be asked to rank improvements in education, healthcare, employment in the municipal sector, economic activity in general, security, and fight against poverty. This will allow us to (i) collect data about saliency of different policy areas for voters; and (ii) prime respondents to think about the importance of different policy areas, and thus simulate the conditions in which voters decide their vote during electoral campaigns. Immediately before the experiment, we will inform voters about IDEB (what it is and what it means for a municipality to meet its IDEB target), and ask them whether they had already heard about it. Rather than use a vignette experiment with information about a hypothetical mayor, we provide real-world information about the performance of the mayor (or former mayor) of the respondent's self-reported municipality. Respondents will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: control (where they are not given information about whether their municipality met its target) and treatment (where they are informed about whether their municipality met its school quality target, as per the data published in 2016). Those in the treatment group read the following question: “In the year 2016, at the end of the term of Mayor [Name], [Municipality] [did not achieve / achieved] its IDEB target. Have you heard about that result?” The treatment information is accompanied by two images designed to reinforce the message: a photograph of the mayor (obtained from the official repository of the Supreme Electoral Court) and a red cross or a green checkmark, depending on the municipality's IDEB performance. Those assigned to the control group do not read any version of this question or a substitute. Next, all respondents, regardless of random assignment, read the following text: "Thinking about [Mayor], do you agree or disagree with the following statements about [his/her] term as Mayor of [municipality] during the period 2012–2016?" Response options are on a 4-point Likert scale ("totally agree", "partially agree", "partially disagree", "totally disagree"). To collect outcome data, we will ask about their agreement with the following statements, with the order of items randomized within respondents: • As mayor, he/she hired a lot of public servants. • As mayor, he/she improved municipal health clinics. • As mayor, he/she helped people like you solve problems. • As mayor, he/she reduced poverty in the municipality. • As mayor, he/she improved municipal schools. • As mayor, he/she invested a lot of money in education. After these main outcomes, we will ask respondents whether they would vote for that mayor if they were to run for another term, again with response options being in a 4-point Likert scale from "great chance" to "no chance".
